data.description: An intensive introduction to the grammar and vocabulary of Classical (Biblical) Hebrew, the language of the Hebrew Bible and Ancient Israel, equivalent toHEBR-BIB 103and104. Gain skills in preparation for reading the Hebrew Bible in the original language. Focus on translation of Hebrew text (written grammar and lexicon). Includes aspects of ancient Israelite culture, history, and literature.
data.title: INTENSIVE ELEMENTARY  BIBLICAL HEBREW

data.description: An introduction to the thought, literature, and history of the prophets of ancient Israel (in English).
data.title: PROPHETS OF THE BIBLE

data.description: Critical reading of selected texts from the Latter Prophets and the Writings.
data.title: BIBLICAL TEXTS, POETRY

data.description: Critical reading of selected texts from the Minor Prophets and the Writings.
data.title: BIBLICAL TEXTS, POETRY

data.description: Forms and syntax, reading of Classical Hebrew prose in preparation for research.
data.title: ELEMENTARY BIBLICAL HEBREW, I

data.description: Forms and syntax, reading of Classical Hebrew prose in preparation for research.
data.title: ELEMENTARY BIBLICAL HEBREW, II

data.description: Grammar and readings in Biblical Aramaic (Daniel, Ezra).
data.title: ARAMAIC I

data.description: Independent study as arranged with a faculty member.

data.title: RESEARCH AND THESIS

data.description: Introduction to the language of the Hebrew Bible (Biblical Hebrew). Serves as basis for later forms of Classical Hebrew.
data.title: ELEMENTARY BIBLICAL HEBREW, I

data.description: Introduction to the language of the Hebrew Bible (Biblical Hebrew). Serves as basis for later forms of Classical Hebrew.
data.title: ELEMENTARY BIBLICAL HEBREW, II

data.description: Introduction to the text, development, history, and social context of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament. Covers the Torah (Pentateuch), Neviim (Former and Latter Prophets), and Ketuvim (Writings), and provides a brief introduction to early Jewish literature (Pseudepigrapha/Apocrypha). Discusses various methods of analysis and theories of composition. Addresses major theological claims made of the text by Jewish and Christian communities. Explores contextualized interpretations in the ancient and modern day.
data.title: INTRODUCTION TO BIBLICAL LITERATURE (IN ENGLISH)

data.description: Provides graduate-level instruction in languages required for research in the literature, history, and culture of the Ancient Near East. Languages typically offered include Akkadian, Phoenician, Sumerian, Hittite, and Egyptian.
data.title: ADVANCED NEAR EASTERN LANGUAGES

data.description: Review of grammar, introduction to reading narrative texts in Biblical Hebrew.
data.title: INTERMEDIATE BIBLICAL HEBREW, I

data.description: Review of grammar, introduction to reading narrative texts in Biblical Hebrew.
data.title: INTERMEDIATE BIBLICAL HEBREW, II

data.description: Selections from non-biblical Aramaic texts: Inscriptions, Elephentine letters, Ahiqar, Targumim.
data.title: ARAMAIC II

data.description: The phonology, morphology and syntax of biblical Hebrew; viewed from historical and descriptive linguistic perspectives.
data.title: CLASSICAL HEBREW LINGUISTICS:  HISTORICAL AND DESCRIPTIVE
